title: 103_hr107
content:
The Act is titled the "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" and is applicable to Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress, including the Social Security Act and the National Labor Relations Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws to Congress, including the Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act, Occupational Safety and Health Act, Title IX of the Education Amendments, Rehabilitation Act, Privacy Act, and Age Discrimination Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws to Congress, including the Freedom of Information Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. Congress and its instrumentalities are subject to the same extent as Executive agencies under the Freedom of Information Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies the Freedom of Information Act to Congress and its instrumentalities, making them subject to the same extent as Executive agencies. Chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code, relating to independent counsel, also applies to Congress. This Act covers Senators, Representatives, Resident Commissioners, Delegates, and employees of either House of Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to various individuals including Senators, Representatives, employees of Congress, Capitol Police, and others as specified in section 591(b) of title 28, United States Code. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to individuals such as Senators, Representatives, Capitol Police, and employees of Congress, including those working in various instrumentalities of Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to individuals working in Congress, including Senators, Representatives, Capitol Police, and employees of Congress. It includes provisions regarding the treatment of employees in the district or State office of a Member, consideration of political affiliation and residence for employment, and a repeal of a section of the Americans with Disabilities Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 includes provisions on the treatment of employees in Congress, consideration of political affiliation and residence for employment, and a repeal of a section of the Americans with Disabilities Act. It also addresses the application of small business exemptions to Members based on the number of employees. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS.

Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the House and Senate must create rules to implement the Act, in line with Federal law. Failure to do so will subject a House of Congress to Executive agency regulations.

SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL.

Individuals affected by this Act can appeal actions in Federal court, with rights and remedies as private persons under relevant laws.
